results.abstract: Films Marius and Jeannette, Blue Streak, The Swindle and The Astronaut's Wife released as new videos; brief excerpts from original reviews; photo (M)
results.snippet: Marius and Jeannette      As surely as romance develops between Jeannette (Ariane Ascaride, left), a supermarket cashier and single mother of two, and Marius (Gerard Meylan), a security guard, Robert Guediguian's film becomes a love affair with the...
results.lead_paragraph: Marius and Jeannette As surely as romance develops between Jeannette (Ariane Ascaride, left), a supermarket cashier and single mother of two, and Marius (Gerard Meylan), a security guard, Robert Guediguian's film becomes a love affair with the working class of Marseilles. Having lost her job, the resilient Jeannette makes the best of it amid neighbors who get through hard times by sharing warm friendships and populist political ideas. One of her sons, by different men, is Catholic, while the other is Muslim, adding religious considerations to a warm, rich film with ''a strong, hearty, down-to-earth spirit throughout,'' Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. 1998. New Yorker. $89.98. 102 minutes. French with English subtitles. No rating.

results.abstract: Article, describing science lesson at elementary school in Scarsdale, NY, notes that, because science is changing so rapidly, demonstrations are no longer textbook driven and Internet is becoming more important resource for teachers and well as students; photos (M)
results.snippet: WITH goggles on their faces and pencils poised above lab sheets, the sixth graders in Alan Cass's classroom at the Seely Place Elementary School here gathered around the rug, staring at a small clear plastic film container. It was filled with water...
results.section_name: Technology; Science; Education; New York and Region
results.lead_paragraph: WITH goggles on their faces and pencils poised above lab sheets, the sixth graders in Alan Cass's classroom at the Seely Place Elementary School here gathered around the rug, staring at a small clear plastic film container. It was filled with water and a dissolvable antacid tablet as part of an experiment designed to demonstrate how pressure propels rockets. Except it just sat there, on the simulated launch pad. A dud. Not to worry. Without missing a beat, Mr. Cass, in a NASA jumpsuit embellished with space patches (the kind that resemble an auto mechanic's, not the astronauts from ''E.T.''), seized the opportunity to teach another kind of lesson instead of the one in the lesson plan.

results.abstract: Sen John McCain, campaigning in Michigan, levels scorching and sustained attacks on Gov George W Bush's reform credentials, while Bush stays upbeat and campaigns as if he were already in the general election; it is as if Bush's victory in South Carolina primary has forced candidates to exchange the roles they played during the nearly three-week campaign in South; Bush confines his attacks on Pres Clinton and Vice Pres Al Gore, allowing surrogates to go after McCain; McCain appeals to Catholic voters by chiding Bush for not speaking out against anti-Catholicism at Bob Jones University (M)

headline.main: BUSH AND MCCAIN SWAP STRATEGIES FOR NEXT BATTLE

results.snippet: As the bitter fight for the Republican presidential nomination shifted to Michigan, Senator John McCain leveled scorching and sustained attacks today on Gov. George W. Bush's reform credentials, while his rival stayed upbeat and campaigned as if he...

byline.original: By ALISON MITCHELL with FRANK BRUNI

results.lead_paragraph: As the bitter fight for the Republican presidential nomination shifted to Michigan, Senator John McCain leveled scorching and sustained attacks today on Gov. George W. Bush's reform credentials, while his rival stayed upbeat and campaigned as if he were already in the general election. Just one day after Mr. Bush's double-digit victory in South Carolina decisively restored his front-runner status, it was as if the two candidates had exchanged the roles they had played in the nearly three-week campaign in the South.

results.abstract: Republican presidential candidate Sen John McCain moves to regain initiative in Michigan following defeat by Gov George W Bush in South Carolina primary; senior campaign officials say his hopes of snatching Republican nomination will be effectively over if he fails to win in Michigan; big quandry for McCain is how to respond to relentless barrage of negative television commercials by Bush campaign; photo (M)

headline.main: After Stumbling in South Carolina, McCain Is Trying to Regain His Footing

results.snippet: Senator John McCain's high command huddled conspiratorially in the darkened aisle of his campaign plane on Sunday night, plotting its latest move to stop Gov. George W. Bush.    They fretted that Mr. Bush had been scheduled to appear first on the...
results.lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain's high command huddled conspiratorially in the darkened aisle of his campaign plane on Sunday night, plotting its latest move to stop Gov. George W. Bush. They fretted that Mr. Bush had been scheduled to appear first on the ''Today'' program on Monday, followed by Mr. McCain. No way, they decided. Mr. McCain would get what they considered the preferred first slot on the highest rated morning program or defect to ''Good Morning America.''

results.abstract: Joyce Cohen article on Internet sites dedicated to Leap Year, such as information for people born on Leap Year Day (www.leapdaybabies.com), Worldwide Leap Year Festival, Anthony, Texas, (www.leapyearcapital.org), origin of leap year and history of the calendar (astro.nmsu,edu/lhuber/le apyear.html), site of astronomy department at New Mexico State University; photo (M)

headline.main: Sites Help Leaplings Bridge Birthday Gap

results.snippet: PEOPLE born on Feb. 29 know just what to expect when others hear about their singular birthday. Many people don't believe them. Some exclaim, ''You poor thing!'' Others say, ''Lucky you.''     Raenell Dawn knows she's lucky. Born on Feb. 29, 1960,...
results.lead_paragraph: PEOPLE born on Feb. 29 know just what to expect when others hear about their singular birthday. Many people don't believe them. Some exclaim, ''You poor thing!'' Others say, ''Lucky you.'' Raenell Dawn knows she's lucky. Born on Feb. 29, 1960, she leads the Honor Society of Leap Day Babies, a group of people born on that distinctive day. The group functions primarily through its Web site, www.leapdaybabies.com.
